weeks.topic: What is Psychology? Psychology as a Science
learning_objectives: Understand the definition and origins of psychology
Trace the historical development of psychology from 1879 to present
Identify the relationship between psychology and other disciplines (engineering, business, EFL, PSIR)
Recognize the main areas of psychology
Understand the scientific method in psychology and its challenges

key_concepts.definition: The scientific study of the mind, brain, and behaviour, exploring thoughts, emotions, and actions to understand individuals and groups. Etymology: psyche (mind, soul, spirit) + logos (knowledge, study).
key_concepts.importance: Foundation concept - establishes psychology as scientific discipline

key_concepts.definition: Founded first experimental psychology laboratory in Leipzig, Germany. Introduced introspection and structuralism (study of structure of the mind).
key_concepts.importance: Marks psychology's separation from philosophy as independent science

key_concepts.definition: Developed functionalism - focused on function of the mind and individual differences rather than just structure.
key_concepts.importance: Shifted focus from 'what is the mind' to 'what does the mind do'

key_concepts.definition: Rejected introspection, emphasized observable behavior. Famous for Little Albert experiment demonstrating classical conditioning in humans.
key_concepts.importance: Made psychology more objective and measurable

key_concepts.definition: Shift to scientific study of mental processes using computer models. Key figures: McCarthy (coined 'artificial intelligence'), Chomsky, George Miller.
key_concepts.importance: Brought mind back into psychology after behaviorism's dominance

key_concepts.definition: 1) Empirical evidence (observable, measurable data), 2) Hypothesis testing, 3) Testable theories, 4) Experimentation (cause-effect), 5) Quantitative/qualitative methods, 6) Falsifiability.
key_concepts.importance: Establishes psychology as legitimate science

key_concepts.definition: 'Looking inside' - systematic self-observation of conscious experience. Pioneered by Wundt.
key_concepts.importance: Early method, criticized by Watson as too subjective

key_concepts.definition: Wundt's approach focusing on identifying the structure/components of the mind.
key_concepts.importance: First systematic psychological theory

key_concepts.definition: William James's approach examining the function and purpose of mental processes and behavior.
key_concepts.importance: Influenced educational and industrial psychology

key_concepts.definition: When researcher's expectations influence experiment results.
key_concepts.importance: Key methodological challenge in psychological research

key_concepts.definition: Cues that might reveal experiment's purpose, causing participants to change behavior.
key_concepts.importance: Threatens validity of psychological experiments

key_concepts.definition: Internal: observed effects are due to IV manipulation. External: results generalizable to other settings/populations/times.
key_concepts.importance: Trade-off in experimental design - laboratory control vs real-world applicability

key_concepts.definition: Ivan Pavlov (1904) - learning through association. Demonstrated with dogs salivating to bell.
key_concepts.importance: Foundation of behaviorist approach to learning

key_concepts.definition: B.F. Skinner (1935) - learning through consequences (reinforcement/punishment).
key_concepts.importance: Explains voluntary behavior modification

key_concepts.definition: Studies of perception emphasizing 'the whole is greater than sum of parts'.
key_concepts.importance: Influenced cognitive psychology and visual perception research

key_concepts.definition: Martin Seligman's approach focusing on well-being and human strengths rather than just pathology.
key_concepts.importance: Expanded psychology beyond treating mental illness

key_concepts.definition: Twin studies to explore heritability of psychological traits.
key_concepts.importance: Modern integration of genetics with psychology

key_concepts.definition: Sigmund Freud (1886) - talk therapy exploring unconscious mind.
key_concepts.importance: Introduced therapeutic approach and unconscious processes

key_concepts.definition: James McKeen Cattell (1888) - standardized psychological measurements.
key_concepts.importance: Founded psychometrics and psychological assessment

key_concepts.definition: Alfred Binet (1905) - first intelligence test for measuring cognition empirically.
key_concepts.importance: Revolutionary tool for educational and clinical assessment

important_studies.description: Demonstrated classical conditioning in humans - taught infant to fear white rat through association with loud noise.
important_studies.significance: Proved behaviorist principles apply to human emotions

important_studies.description: Systematic self-experimentation on memory using nonsense syllables.
Dogs learned to salivate to bell that predicted food.
important_studies.significance: Discovered classical conditioning - foundational learning principle
Demonstrated operant conditioning and behavior modification

applications.application: Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), user experience, cybersecurity, AI development
Understanding human error and stress in system design
How buildings and cities affect mental health and behavior
Designing devices to monitor stress, mood, cognitive performance
Neuropsychology collaboration for brain-affecting drug development
Aviation psychology - pilot cognition, fatigue, decision-making
Understanding cognitive, emotional, social, motivational processes in language learning
Human behavior, cognition, emotions underpin political dynamics

timeline_highlights: 1879 - Wundt opens first experimental psychology lab (Leipzig)
1883 - Stanley Hall opens first U.S. psychology lab (Johns Hopkins)
challenges_in_psychology: Social nature of science - objectivity problem (psychologists part of their subject matter)
Psychology experiment as social situation (experimenter bias, demand characteristics)

learning_objectives: Understand the biopsychological approach and behavior genetics methods
Explain behaviorist principles (classical and operant conditioning)
Describe psychodynamic theory including Freud's personality structure and psychosexual stages
Identify humanistic psychology's key concepts (self-actualization, unconditional positive regard)
Explain evolutionary psychology's principles and applications

key_concepts.definition: Emphasizes that psychological phenomena are rooted in biological processes - brain, nervous system, genetics, endocrine system. Studies nature vs nurture.
key_concepts.importance: Links mental states to measurable biological mechanisms

key_concepts.definition: Studies three sources of trait variation: 1) genetic differences, 2) shared environments, 3) non-shared environments. Examples: intelligence, personality, addiction.
key_concepts.importance: Quantifies heredity vs environment contributions

key_concepts.definition: Compare Monozygotic (MZ, 100% DNA) vs Dizygotic (DZ, 50% DNA) twins to estimate heritability through concordance rates. Assumes equal environments assumption.
key_concepts.importance: Gold standard for separating genetic from environmental factors

key_concepts.definition: Compare adopted children to biological parents (genetic) vs adoptive parents (environment) to isolate influences.
key_concepts.importance: Natural experiment separating nature and nurture

key_concepts.definition: Measure of similarity between twins for a trait. Higher MZ than DZ concordance suggests genetic influence.
key_concepts.importance: Quantitative measure of heritability

key_concepts.definition: Learning where neutral stimulus becomes associated with unconditioned stimulus to elicit conditioned response. UCS → UCR becomes CS → CR.
key_concepts.importance: Explains automatic emotional responses and phobias

key_concepts.definition: Learning through consequences: Positive Reinforcement (add reward), Negative Reinforcement (remove aversive), Positive Punishment (add aversive), Negative Punishment (remove reward).
key_concepts.importance: Explains voluntary behavior modification

key_concepts.definition: Behaviorist assumption that humans start as blank slates, shaped entirely by experience and learning.
key_concepts.importance: Contrasts with nativist views emphasizing innate knowledge

key_concepts.definition: Behaviorist belief that behavior is primarily determined by external stimuli and reinforcements, not free will.
key_concepts.importance: Philosophical foundation of behaviorism

key_concepts.definition: Freud's theory emphasizing unconscious forces, infantile sexuality, early experience impact. Includes later theorists Jung, Adler, Erikson.
key_concepts.importance: First comprehensive personality theory

key_concepts.definition: Conscious (aware), Pre-conscious (retrievable memories), Unconscious (hidden drives, repressed memories).
key_concepts.importance: Revolutionary concept that most mental activity is unconscious

key_concepts.definition: Id (pleasure principle - immediate gratification), Ego (reality principle - mediates), Superego (morality principle - conscience).
key_concepts.importance: Explains internal psychological conflicts

key_concepts.definition: Freud's developmental stages: Oral, Anal, Phallic, Latency, Genital. Fixation at any stage affects adult personality.
key_concepts.importance: Links childhood experiences to adult personality

key_concepts.definition: Unconscious strategies ego uses to manage anxiety (e.g., repression, denial, projection, sublimation).
key_concepts.importance: Explains how people cope with threatening thoughts/feelings

key_concepts.definition: Emphasizes free will, personal growth, self-actualization, subjective experience. Rejects determinism of psychoanalysis and behaviorism.
key_concepts.importance: Focuses on human potential rather than pathology

key_concepts.definition: Peak of hierarchy of needs - realizing full potential. Needs hierarchy: Physiological → Safety → Belongingness → Esteem → Self-Actualization.
key_concepts.importance: Provides developmental framework for human motivation

key_concepts.definition: Individual's perception of self. Healthy development requires congruence between perceived self and actual self.
key_concepts.importance: Central to Rogers' person-centered therapy

key_concepts.definition: Acceptance and support regardless of what person says or does. Contrasts with conditions of worth.
key_concepts.importance: Essential therapeutic condition for personal growth

key_concepts.definition: Person who experiences congruence between self-concept and experience, lives authentically.
key_concepts.importance: Ideal outcome of humanistic therapy

key_concepts.definition: Focuses on mental processes (perception, memory, thinking, problem-solving, decision-making). Views mind as information-processing system like computer.
key_concepts.importance: Bridges behaviorism and neuroscience

key_concepts.definition: Internal mental representations of spatial environments. Demonstrated that rats learn maze layout, not just turns.
key_concepts.importance: Early evidence that learning involves mental representations, not just S-R connections

key_concepts.definition: Computer analogy - mind encodes, stores, retrieves information like computer processes data.
key_concepts.importance: Dominant metaphor in modern cognitive psychology

key_concepts.definition: Explains mental and behavioral traits as adaptations shaped by natural selection. Mind consists of specialized modules for survival/reproduction problems.
key_concepts.importance: Integrates biology with psychology

key_concepts.definition: Challenges in ancestral environments (finding food, selecting mates, avoiding predators) that shaped cognitive mechanisms.
key_concepts.importance: Explains why certain behaviors are universal

key_concepts.definition: Specialized mental mechanisms designed to solve specific adaptive problems. Assumed to be universal and fixed.
key_concepts.importance: Evolutionary explanation for domain-specific cognition

important_studies.description: Dogs salivated to bell (CS) that predicted food (UCS), demonstrating classical conditioning.
Infant conditioned to fear white rat through pairing with loud noise.
important_studies.significance: Demonstrated classical conditioning applies to human emotions

important_studies.description: Rats/pigeons learned behaviors through reinforcement schedules in controlled chamber.
Cross-cultural study showing men prefer physical attractiveness, women prefer resources.
important_studies.significance: Evolutionary psychology evidence for sex differences in mate selection

important_studies.description: Men more distressed by sexual infidelity, women by emotional infidelity.
Innate fears may have evolved to protect from ancestral threats.
important_studies.significance: Preparedness theory - some fears easier to acquire

key_figures.name: John Watson
key_figures.contribution: Applied behaviorism to humans, Little Albert experiment

key_figures.name: Sigmund Freud
key_figures.contribution: Psychoanalytic theory, unconscious mind, psychosexual development

key_figures.name: David Buss
key_figures.contribution: Evolutionary psychology research on mate selection

applications.application: Understanding schizophrenia (excess dopamine), depression (low serotonin), addiction (dopamine reward pathways)
Behavior modification, treatment of phobias, addiction treatment, education
Psychoanalytic therapy, understanding personality disorders, dream analysis
Person-centered therapy, counseling, positive psychology interventions
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), Artificial Intelligence, memory enhancement techniques
Understanding mate selection, parenting strategies, fear responses, social behavior

criticisms: Reductionism - oversimplifies complex behaviors to biology
Ethical concerns with animal testing and genetic editing
Determinism - ignores neuroplasticity and environmental influence
Overemphasis on observable behavior, ignores mental processes
Neglects innate factors and biological predispositions
Overreliance on animal studies - generalization issues
Deterministic view - denies free will
Ethical concerns (Little Albert experiment)
Fails to address individual differences
Lack of empirical evidence, unfalsifiable concepts
Overemphasis on sexuality
Gender bias (penis envy, Oedipus complex)
Neglects social and cultural influences
Concepts difficult to test empirically
Overly optimistic view of human nature
Overemphasis on subjective experiences
Overemphasis on mental processes, neglects emotions
Computer metaphor oversimplifies cognition
Reductionist - ignores holistic experience
Falsifiability issues - hard to test ancestral claims
Reductionism - reduces complex behaviors to adaptation
Misinterpretation risk - may justify social inequalities

comparison_summary.determinism_vs_free_will: Biopsychological, Behaviorist, and Psychodynamic approaches are deterministic. Humanistic emphasizes free will. Cognitive and Evolutionary are mixed.
comparison_summary.nature_vs_nurture: Biopsychological emphasizes nature. Behaviorist emphasizes nurture. Others integrate both.
comparison_summary.focus: Behaviorist: observable behavior. Psychodynamic: unconscious. Humanistic: subjective experience. Cognitive: mental processes. Evolutionary: adaptive functions.
